This was especially true during the establishment of the kingdom by the Magyars in the early medieval period. However, over time, the monarchy became more hereditary, and the practice of electing rulers diminished. By the 13th century, with the issuance of the Golden Bull of 1222, the monarchy had shifted towards a hereditary system, where the king was no longer elected but rather passed the throne to his heirs. Thus, while landowners may have had a role in electing rulers early on, this practice was not sustained throughout the kingdom's history.
